text: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन। मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते संगोऽस्त्वकर्मणि॥ You have a right to perform your prescribed duties, but you are not entitled to the fruits of your actions. Never consider yourself to be the cause of the results of your activities, nor be attached to inaction. Context: This verse from Chapter 2 emphasizes selfless action and detachment from outcomes.

योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते॥ Be steadfast in the performance of your duty, O Arjuna, abandoning attachment to success and failure. Such equanimity is called Yoga. Context: This verse defines the essence of Karma Yoga as maintaining equanimity in success and failure.

ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते। सङ्गात्सञ्जायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते॥ While contemplating the objects of the senses, a person develops attachment to them; attachment gives rise to desire, and desire gives rise to anger. Context: This verse from Chapter 2 discusses the chain reaction of desire and its consequences.
